landing_banner_intro: CAT (Comfort-based Accessibility Tool) helps you explore walkable areas not only by time and speed, but also by perceived comfort factors, such as noise, lighting, crossings, tactile paving, tree shade, and more. Pick a start point, tune what matters to you, and see how the reachable area changes.
landing_banner_contact_caption: Are you interested in having the tool for your city?
landing_city_hamburg_desc: Germany’s second-largest city, Hamburg combines historic port landscapes with diverse, walkable urban districts and advanced public transport.
landing_city_penteli_desc: Overlooking Athens, Penteli features green residential areas and hilly terrain, shaping its unique accessibility and urban mobility.
landing_details_blocks: The Comfort-Based Accessibility Tool (CAT) was developed at the Technical University of Munich to support data-driven, people-centered urban planning. Using information from literature and interviews with planning experts and people with limited mobility capabilities, the tool offers a comprehensive approach to visualizing comfort-based accessibility.

CAT integrates travel time, walking speed, and a range of comfort factors to generate dynamic, personalized comfort-based accessibility analyses and isochrone maps. Users can interactively select which factors matter most, and see how their accessibility area changes.

CAT is aimed at city planners, mobility researchers, policymakers, and organizations seeking to improve urban accessibility and comfort for all pedestrians and wheelchair users. At the same time, the tool is also available to the general public, who can use it to explore how accessibility changes according to their individual comfort preferences.

Advantages: The platform allows for scenario testing, stakeholder participation, and transparent communication of walkability challenges, making it a practical decision-support tool for inclusive, resilient urban development.
landing_general_title: General information about the research project
landing_general_blocks: With a design-for-all approach, the project InclusiveSpaces is designing, monitoring, and evaluating urban spaces to ensure they are inclusive, accessible, and climate adaptive. By introducing co-design accessibility concepts, we engage people with in vulnerable situations to enhance inclusiveness, social cohesion, and climate change mitigation and adaptation. InclusiveSpaces is an initiative to standardise and digitise design frameworks towards a transition to an inclusive and climate-friendly built environment.

InclusiveSpaces develops innovative planning tools and assistive technologies rooted in universal design principles, empowering diverse user groups and advancing climate-friendly practices. These solutions are demonstrated and evaluated in six European cities: Athens-Penteli, Geneva, Madrid, Larnaka, Hamburg, and Budapest.

InclusiveSpaces is a Horizon Europe project supported by the European Commission under Grant Agreement No. 101147881. The UK participants in this project are co-funded by the UK. Views and opinions expressed are however those of the author(s) only and do not necessarily reflect those of the European Union or European Climate, Infrastructure and Environment Executive Agency (CINEA). Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them.
The InclusiveSpaces project is funded under the framework of the Built4People partnership.

modal_help_title: Welcome to the Comfort-Based Accessibility Tool!
modal_help_intro: This tool helps you explore how walkable a location is based on your comfort preferences.
modal_howto_step_select_start: Click “Select Start Point” and pick a location on the map.
modal_howto_step_adjust: Adjust your walking time and speed using the sliders.
modal_howto_step_enable_features: Enable features like Noise, Light, or Trees.
modal_howto_step_get_area: Click “Get Catchment Area” to visualize zones.
modal_howto_step_view_results: View results in the legend panel.
modal_tips_step_toggle_layers: Toggle layers using the left-side menu
modal_tips_step_adjust_weights: Adjust comfort weights, and click “Get Catchment Area” again to get new area
modal_tips_step_reset: Press “Reset” to remove all results and start fresh
modal_outro: Let’s make your journey more comfortable and inclusive!
tooltip_walking_speed_intro: Adjust your walking speed based on your comfort:
tooltip_walking_speed_stroll: A relaxed stroll (slow) is usually around 3–4 km/h.
tooltip_walking_speed_average: An average (medium), steady pace for most people is about 5 km/h.
tooltip_walking_speed_brisk: A brisk walk (fast), such as when you’re in a hurry, can reach 6 km/h.
tooltip_variable_title: Tick the comfort factors that matter to you and adjust how much they bother you with the sliders below.
tooltip_noise: Is high traffic or environmental noise here likely to stress you and make you avoid walking?
tooltip_light: Would insufficient or missing street lighting make this street feel unsafe to you after dark?
tooltip_traffic: Does crossing here without traffic lights feel dangerous, especially on busy roads?
tooltip_tactile: Would the lack of tactile paving hinder independent navigation for visually impaired pedestrians here?
tooltip_tree: Does walking on a path without tree shade feel too exposed and hot for comfort?
tooltip_summer: Would high surface temperatures in this area discourage you from walking?
tooltip_winter: In cold or icy conditions, would walking on this path feel dangerous or strenuous to you?
tooltip_green: Does the absence of green space here make the area feel uninviting or lacking places to rest?
tooltip_blue: Without water features, does this place feel less pleasant or have a poorer micro-climate to you?
tooltip_station: Does limited access to public transport here make the area less walkable for your longer trips?
tooltip_narrow: Do narrow or obstructed sidewalks here feel hazardous, especially for wheelchairs or strollers?
tooltip_wc: Would the lack of accessible toilets nearby limit your willingness to walk here?
tooltip_stair: Does the presence of stairs, without any accessible ramp or pathway, make it difficult for you to access the area?
tooltip_obstacle: Do obstacles or blockages here make walking routes confusing or unsafe for you?
tooltip_slope: Would steep slopes here make walking more tiring, dangerous, or inaccessible to you?
tooltip_uneven: Does an uneven surface here increase your risk of tripping or falling?
tooltip_poor: Does poor pavement quality here make walking uncomfortable or hazardous for you?
tooltip_kerb: Do high or abrupt kerbs here make crossing or transitioning paths more difficult?
tooltip_facility: Would the lack of nearby facilities (shops, benches, rest areas) reduce your willingness to walk here?
tooltip_crowd: Does a high level of crowding here make walking feel stressful, uncomfortable, or unsafe to you?
tooltip_data_source_hh: Mainly sourced from Geoportal Hamburg, OpenStreetMap, and the Technical University of Munich. For detailed information, please refer to the source indicated under each dataset below.
tooltip_data_source_pt: Mainly sourced from the municipality of Penteli, OpenStreetMap, and the Technical University of Munich. For detailed information, please refer to the source indicated under each dataset below.
tooltip_data_desc: The map layers combine environmental, infrastructural, and accessibility-related data from open data source. They include information such as noise, temperature, light, slope, greenery, street infrastructure, and pedestrian flow, supporting comfort-based accessibility analysis.
tooltip_layer_generic_desc: This layer visualizes city features used for comfort-based accessibility insights.

noise_wms.title: Noise Map
noise_wms.desc: Day-evening-night noise levels from Hamburg Geoportal WMS.

temp_summer.title: Summer Thermal Comfort
temp_summer.desc: This dataset was generated by converting local thermal comfort sampling points into a 100×100 m raster grid, illustrating spatial variations in summer heat conditions.
temp_summer.source: Provided by Technical University of Munich, Chair of Building Technology and Climate Responsive Design (2025), processed by InclusiveSpaces project.

temp_winter.title: Winter Thermal Comfort
temp_winter.desc: This dataset was generated by converting local thermal comfort sampling points into a 100×100 m raster grid, reflecting spatial patterns of cold stress during the winter season.
temp_winter.source: Provided by Technical University of Munich, Chair of Building Technology and Climate Responsive Design (2025), processed by InclusiveSpaces project.

streetlight.title: Street Lights
streetlight.desc: This dataset contains the location of street lighting points. Each feature represents an individual light pole; grouped or sub-nodes are not included.

trafic_light_wms.title: Traffic Lights
trafic_light_wms.desc: The dataset contains the location, name, and node number of all traffic lights in the Hamburg city area (excluding the Hamburg Port Authority [HPA]). Signalized crossings/junctions, etc., which are defined as sub-nodes of the traffic lights, are not displayed as separate points.

trafic_light.title: Traffic Lights
trafic_light.desc: This dataset includes the locations of signalized intersections and pedestrian crossings.

tactile_guidance.title: Tactile Support Area
tactile_guidance.desc: This dataset represents areas and linear segments equipped with tactile paving or ground-surface indicators that assist visually impaired pedestrians in navigation.

tree_wms.title: Tree Planting Sites
tree_wms.desc: This dataset contains locations of tree planting sites categorized as planted trees, planned trees, and unassigned planting spots. The data originates from Hamburg’s official tree management system and is published via the Geoportal WMS service.

green_infrastructure_wms.title: Green Infrastructure
green_infrastructure_wms.desc: Information about all types of green space - playgrounds, parks, general green spaces, hiking trails, allotment garden green spaces, permanent allotments, protective green spaces, sports fields and cemeteries.

green_infrastructure.title: Green Infrastructure
green_infrastructure.desc: Information about the public and natural green areas, including parks, vegetation zones, and open landscape patches.

blue_infrastructure_wms.title: Blue Infrastructure (Water Features)
blue_infrastructure_wms.desc: This dataset includes hydrological and geomorphological features such as rivers, lakes, and other water-related landmarks relevant for geotourism and landscape interpretation.

transport_station_wms.title: Public Transport Stations
transport_station_wms.desc: This dataset is part of the Hamburg Metropolitan Region’s accessibility analysis (Erreichbarkeitsanalysen) and contains destinations and facilities relevant for mobility studies, including train stations, bus stops, schools, commercial centers, and supermarkets. The data supports regional accessibility and service coverage assessments.

transport_station.title: Public Transport Stations
transport_station.desc: This dataset contains the locations of public bus stops.

wc_disabled.title: Accessible Toilets
wc_disabled.desc: This dataset contains the locations of public toilets equipped with wheelchair-accessible facilities.

sidewalk_narrow.title: Narrow Sidewalks
sidewalk_narrow.desc: This dataset identifies sidewalks narrower than 2 meters, based on street geometry and width attributes extracted from OpenStreetMap. These segments are considered potentially uncomfortable or difficult to use for pedestrians, wheelchair users, or strollers.

stair.title: Stairs
stair.desc: This dataset was extracted from OpenStreetMap features tagged as 'highway=steps'. It includes outdoor stairways and stepped paths that may act as barriers for people with limited mobility or wheelchair users.

obstacle.title: Obstacles
obstacle.desc: This dataset was derived from OpenStreetMap features representing permanent or temporary objects that may block or narrow pedestrian pathways, such as bollards, barriers, or construction sites. These features were selected using tags like 'barrier=*' and other obstruction-related attributes.

slope.title: Slope
slope.desc: This dataset identifies street segments with noticeable inclines or declines, derived from elevation attributes and road geometry in OpenStreetMap. Steeper slopes may reduce accessibility or increase walking effort for people with mobility limitations.

slope_penteli.title: Slope
slope_penteli.desc: This dataset represents street segments with calculated slope values derived from digital elevation models (DEM) along the road network. Segments with higher slopes may pose challenges for pedestrians, wheelchair users, or cyclists in terms of accessibility and comfort.
slope_penteli.source: Provided by municipality of Penteli (2025), processed by InclusiveSpaces project

uneven_surfaces.title: Uneven Surfaces
uneven_surfaces.desc: This dataset identifies street or sidewalk segments with uneven or irregular surfaces that may reduce walking comfort or accessibility. Features were selected from OpenStreetMap where surface conditions or tags indicate roughness, cobblestones, or damaged pavement.

poor_pavement.title: Poor Pavement Quality
poor_pavement.desc: This dataset identifies road or sidewalk segments with degraded pavement quality, such as cracks, potholes, or damaged surfaces. The features were filtered from OpenStreetMap using surface condition tags indicating low smoothness or poor material quality.

kerbs_high.title: High Kerbs
kerbs_high.desc: This dataset highlights street crossings or edges where kerb height exceeds accessibility-friendly standards. The data was extracted from OpenStreetMap features tagged with 'kerb=raised' or similar attributes that indicate elevated borders impeding wheelchair passage.

facility_wms.title: Public Facilities
facility_wms.desc: This dataset includes facilities related to education and culture, such as cinemas, theaters, museums, music venues, exhibition spaces, community cultural centers, civic halls, specialized libraries, adult education centers, and religious communities.
facility_wms.source: Geoportal Hamburg (Bildung und Kultur Eimsbüttel Hamburg)

facilities.title: Facilities
facilities.desc: Local community, cultural, and educational facilities.

pedestrian_flow_wms.title: Pedestrian Flow
pedestrian_flow_wms.desc: This dataset visualizes the relative importance of streets and paths for pedestrian movement in Hamburg. The significance values were calculated using the city’s digital landscape model and various points of interest (POIs) such as public transport stops, retail areas, and schools. Each POI was assigned an influence area and a weight from 0 to 15, with higher values indicating greater pedestrian relevance.

pedestrian_flow.title: Pedestrian Flow
pedestrian_flow.desc: This dataset represents observed pedestrian movement intensity.

alert_no_area_time_speed: No reachable area found for this walking time/speed. Please try another setting.
alert_no_area_comfort: The selected comfort settings result in no reachable area. Try adjusting the sliders.
